lg.l: Except for those who have come to the feet of the Gracious One, the ocean of Dharma,
to cross the other ocean is hard.

div.p: (i-ḷ). aṟakkaṭalākiya antaṇaṉatu tāḷākiya puṇaiyaic cērntārkkallatu ataṉiṟ piṟavākiya kaṭalkaḷai nīntal aritu, (e-ṟu).

The meaning ... : Except those who have reached the boat that is the feet of the Gracious One(?) Who is an ocean of dharma (aṟam), it is difficult to cross the oceans that are different from that one.

aṟam poru ḷiṉpameṉa uṭaṉeṇṇappaṭṭa mūṉṟaṉuḷ aṟattai muṉṉarppirittamaiyāṉ, ēṉaip poruḷum iṉpamum ‘piṟa’ eṉappaṭṭaṉa. palavēṟu vakaippaṭṭa aṟaṅka ḷellāvaṟṟaiyun taṉakku vaṭivāka uṭaiyaṉākaliṉ ‘aṟavāḻiyantaṇaṉ’ eṉṟār. ‘aṟavāḻi’ eṉpataṉait tarumacakkara mākki ataṉaiyuṭaiya antaṇaṉeṉṟuraippāru muḷar. appuṇaiyaic cērātar karaikāṇā tavaṟṟuḷḷē aḻuntuvarākaliṉ ‘nīntalaritu’ eṉṟār. iḵtēkatēca vuruvakam.

Inasmuch as, among the three [goals of humanity] counted together as dharma (aṟam), welfare (poruḷ), and pleasure (iṉpam), dharma has [here] been separated [and placed] first, the rest, [namely] welfare and pleasure, have been called "other." Because He is the One Who possesses all the dharmas of many different kinds as His Own body, [the poet] has said, "the Gracious One, the ocean of dharma." There are also those who, making the "ocean of dharma" the Wheel of Dharma, explain that the Gracious One [is he who] possesses it. Because those who have not reached that boat drown in those ["oceans," namely the search for wealth/welfare and pleasure] without [ever] seeing [the other] shore, he has said, "to cross is hard." This is a partial rūpaka [because, on this reading, God has been explicitly called an ocean of dharma, and the other two goals of humanity have also been explicitly compared to an ocean; but the comparison of the feet to boats remains implicit—though easy enough to detect in light of Sanskrit parallels].
i - ḷ:—aṟamākiya kaṭalai yuṭaiya antaṇaṉatu tiruvaṭiyaic cērntavark kallatu (oḻinta pērkaḷukku) piṟa āḻiyai nīntal ākātu. avalam nīṅkappeṟutal aritu eṉṟavāṟu.

The meaning is as follows: Apart from those who have come to the holy feet of the Gracious One(?), Who has an ocean(/wheel?) that is dharma, it is impossible—for the rest of humanity (lit. "names")—to swim the other ocean; [in other words?] it is difficult to obtain the departure(?) of distress.
itu, kāmamum poruḷum paṟṟivarum avalam keṭu meṉṟatu.
This [verse] expresses that the distress that comes from [striving for one's] desires (iṉpam) and for wealth (poruḷ) perishes.
